content.description: This is a pretty cool problem with a tricky crux / mantley thing.
content.location: It is just left of center. This has some reasonable climbing up to nice 5.11 ish sequence at 15'. The crux if getting stood up on the sloping shelf.

content.description: Follow the obvious flake up the center of the face.

This is a cool problem that was originally a TR, but now it is a boulder problem with a better landing. Make a thin move to a big reach left on a sloping hold, swing left, and mantle up. Do one more thinnish move to the top.
content.location: On the left side of the face, you can see the sloping just easy.

content.description: This is rather harder than Knightline. Instead of reaching left to the jug, grab a small edge on move straight up on some hard moves. It is quite thin.
content.location: Use the same start as Knightline.

content.description: Do a tricky start to the small ledge (reachy). It got much harder since a key foot hold broke off a few years ago. Mantle up the ledge, and climb the face to the top. It is easier if you trend left.
content.location: This ascends the left side of the wall with a small ledge 10 feet up.

content.description: Start in the slippery dihedral at the right of the face, and climb up through the overhang.
content.protection: A couple small cams and small stoppers.There are eyelet bolts at the top for anchors.

content.description: Climb the face using crimps to the top (without using the small ledge on the right).
content.location: It ascends the face between the flakes and the corner.

content.description: Climb just left of the corner (without using it) to a small ledge. Continue up and left, layback a slopy section, and finish on easier terrain.
content.location: It is just left of the inside corner on the right side.

content.description:
This face lies just to the right of P Face.  It is also known as the Knight Face.  Its base is one of the nicer places here to sit and enjoy while not actually climbing.  This is a really nice piece of rock which can heat up during hot temperatures.  In fact, sticky rubber has been known to melt on this little face during the peak of summer.  This is a great place during colder weather.  There is a large ring at the top of the right side of the face.  Yellow Knight and Knight Line are educational experiences for dime sized edge climbing. 

  L->R:   A. Beeble Berries, 3   B. Double Retable, 7, 1p, TR.   C1. Knightline, 11+ or V2, 1p, TR.   C2. Knight's and Easy, 12- or V4-, 1p, TR.   D. Yellow Knight, 10, 1p, TR.   E. White Knight, 5, 1p, TR.   F1. Big Biner Direct, 9, 1p, TR.   F2. Big Biner, 8, 1p, TR.   G. Black Knight, 5, 1p, TR. 

  A beer for anyone who doesn't already climb 5.11 who can flash Yellow Knight.
